segments.text: You asked me some time ago if religion had an effect on my life.
Really, it didn't.
But in my last, I'm 66 now, I'd say in my last probably 15, 20 years, I realized that there really is a God, and he has an influence on our life, and I pray to him.
But you've become more religious now as you've become older.
Yes.
Why do you think that is?
I think it's nothing more but experience, judgment, and more wisdom.
I'm convinced older person gets more wisdom than he has.
I think that makes sense.
Sure.
A lot of ways I think I'm smarter now than I was when I know I am.
Going back to your original question, when I got out of high school and saw that I couldn't go to West Point, I thought, well, I'll take the written examination to the Flying Cadets.
I know I can do this because of regulations at that time.
I borrowed some books on some subjects that I had not been studying in the West Point Preparatory School in 1935 down at Fort Sam for the West Point Interest Exam.

There were questions in physics, trigonometry, and one or two other subjects on the flying cadet examination that I hadn't been studying in my previous West Point Preparatory School in the United States Army.
So I borrowed a book in physics.
trigonometry, and on my own at home, started studying those subjects.

And then when I went down to, I was one of 14 people, entrance, trying to get into flying cadets at that time, and went to Barksdale Air Force Base in Shreveport, Louisiana, to take a physical examination.
I was only one out of 14 that passed a physical examination, with reservations in my case also, that I had to have
my nose operated on to remove a crooked septum.
And I got that done.
They accepted me physically and then permitted me to take the written examination.
And through the help of some of the instructors at Randolph Air Force Base, whom I had known in the military, in the West Point Prep School,
at Fort Sam.
I passed the examination and I think there I was about, I think it was about two or three out of about 15 or 20 that made that.
So that made me real proud.
And that put me in the flying cadets in March of 1938.
And Randolph
Air Force Base in San Antonio.
Okay, now tell me about the cadets.
Is it basically training?
Oh yes, training and teaching you to fly because I'm a pilot.

It was a one year course, nine months at Randolph Air Force Base divided into primary and basic training where you soloed and then the next four and a half months you got a little bit more advanced airplanes.
Then the last three months, you go over to Kelly Air Force Base, the other side of San Antonio, in those days, and take specialized courses either in bombing, attack, or pursuit or observation.
It was called pursuit in those days, fighter today.
I took fighters or pursuit.
Why did you want to be a fighter pilot instead of bomber or observation?
Well, I liked the glamour of it.
Flying your own airplane, you're the only person in the airplane, and the acrobatics.
It was fun.
It appealed to me.

Also, I developed in those days, just thinking about it, the idea that if I was in an airplane, I could control the airplane myself, and I could fire and shoot at another airplane, whereas if I was sitting in a bomber,
Maybe I have to sit there and let them shoot at me and maybe take it.
Sure.
Fighters appealed to me.
And the first chance I had at Randolph Air Force Base after I soloed, I had been taught to do slow rolls, shown how to do a slow roll by my instructor.
But the first chance I had in flying an airplane by myself, I did a slow roll.
I thought it was the greatest thing in the world.
Now, in 1938, when you went to cadet school, then you went active duty, full-time military.
Yes.
That was the first time.
I graduated from Kelly Field in February of 1939.
And incidentally, there I flew the key slot of the entire graduating class in formation.
Number two man on the lead instructor.
I'm real proud of that.
Again, I turned out to be an A student
And then upon graduation, we were assigned to our first tactical unit.
And upon graduation, is that when you received the permission?
I became a second lieutenant reserve in a Army Air Corps, United States Army Air Corps.
That's in 1939, when you received your first assignment, which was at Langley Field in Virginia.
Right, second bomb group.
And of all things, they put me in bombers.
Yeah, I don't understand that.
I've often asked that question.
I think there were 17 of us in my graduating class that went to Langley Field, and at Langley Field there was an aid pursuit group and a second bomb group, and they had to divide us up, of course.
Well, I think they did alphabetically, and they took the top ones and put them in bombers.
That's the only way I can figure it out.
At any rate, I was put in bombardment, and looking back now, again, the good Lord may have been taking care of me.
I don't know.
Maybe it's fate, but the experience turned out to be worthwhile.
I got some experience in B-17s.
At that time, the Air Force only had 14 B-17s, and I became a pilot of one of those airplanes.
That was unheard of in those days.
You had to be seven feet tall, be...
hundred years old to be a pilot, one of those things.
And I got to go on one of the very few goodwill flights down to South America.
Oh, did you?
In November 1939 with 7B-17.
Really, part of the good neighbor policy.
Right, right.
How did they brief you before you went down?
What did they tell you?
Oh, we went through, I guess it took six months to plan that trip.
Mm-hmm.

At the time, there was no such thing as airwaving or anything, but we used Pan American Airlines as sort of a forerunner, and used their experience, and, well, for instance, we had to fly over the Andes, you know, across from Peru to southern part of Brazil, and followed a route they had established.
Pan Am really blazed the way for the trip.
And incidentally, Kurt LeMay was the first lieutenant navigator for that flight, and I was his assistant operations officer.
And tell me about him.
Fantastic man.
I knew the minute I met that man and worked with him that I knew one of these days he was going to be one of the greatest leaders in aviation.
He was the same way as the first lieutenant that he was as four-star general.
And what way was that?
All business.

He still had an understanding of people, and for some reason or other, I think the reason he took an interest in me is he saw my determination and dedication compared to my fellow second lieutenant that came to Langley Field.
He was a first lieutenant?
He was a first lieutenant, and I was a second lieutenant, of course, and he mainly took me under his wing.
He was just such an operational officer.
What kind of person was he?
He wasn't a gregarious type, a social type.
He was all business, smoked cigars then.
Very much like you saw and have seen pictures and stories of him.
Very, very much the same.
Not near the iron-ass type.
of a person in his heart, not near, in his heart, that people made him out to be.
He was not, if you will, the son of a bitch that Patton was.
He was not that type.
But he was definitely a leader.
He could do anything that he required you to do.
And that impressed me.
He could do it better.
Anything he required you to do,
If you couldn't do it, he'd show you how to do it.
And this Danley, he trained as a fighter pilot, too, in his earlier days.
So how was this trip with him?
Oh, it was fantastic.
As a matter of fact, Curt LeMay was one of the earlier officers I modeled myself after.
Oh, really?
Really, one of the earliest.
I knew he was going to go places.
So you sort of, he was your role model one night?
Not exactly a model.
I guess in those earlier days I didn't have a particular hero or a particular model, but I respected him less.
I respected him more than I did my squadron commander.
I respected competence in my superiors.
I demanded it in my subordinates as I grew up in the military.
But tell me about this trip.
It was nothing in the world but a normalin those days it was a spectacular trip.
Sure.
Four-engine bombers.
How many bombers?
We had five on that trip.
That's that trip, right?
We had some experiences on the trip that in those days were unusual, unexpected.
First, you just didn't have an aircraft that would fly that far.
Whoever heard of the United States Air Force, as you call it today, flying airplanes across the oceans around other countries?
It was unusual in those days.

In foreign countries, the arrangements you had to make, flying over the Andes at altitudes, flying over the Andes at 21,000 feet, puffing on a stick with oxygen in it, and still looking up above you at the peaks.
Those things in those days you wouldn't forget.
And having engines ice up, you know.
The first time here, you know, that's the first experience high altitude flying.
Twenty-one thousand feet, you know, gets unheard of those days.
And then, of course Were you afraid at the time?
No.
I can remember, I was a copilot on that flight for Dono, and my job was to keep those engines running.
We had navigators do the navigation.
My job was to keep the engines performing and using as little fuel as possible, and I loved it.
And when the engines started icing up, I un-iced them.
Just using the mixture control, possibly, and putting the carburetor heat on.
Well-trained.
I knew my job.
That's the reason I was selected.
I was a brand-new second lieutenant going with all these veterans.
Did you lose any planes?
No.
As a matter of fact, we had some accidents.
And of course, my particular aircraft crew was the ones that had some of the misfortunes.
We lost a radio over the Andes on the way from Lima, Peru to Asuncion, Paraguay and got lost.
And it got a little hairy then.
I remember it got a little hairy then.
How'd you find it?
Matter of fact, we didn't find Asuncion Paraguay.
We landed at Sao Paulo, Brazil, but flying, letting down over the water.
You did it with a mountain, not knowing where we are.
Then groping our way back to the coast and finding Sao Paulo, Brazil, and landing there.
And then, the following day, the weather cleared, got a radio fixed, we went on on to Susquehanna Paraguay.
Then, of course, we came up to Rio de Janeiro, won the airplane, got in mud, lost props.
On the way back, last leg from Curacao, Venezuela, on the way to Langley, we lost number three engine and had to go into Jacksonville.
So again, we didn't.
land and all the heroes welcome it by the field, but we finally got back.
Tremendous experience.
What did you learn from it?
Well, what a four-engine bomber can do, particularly from a standpoint of transportation, not necessary bombings.
And also, the impact that you can have in a show of force of military
What was the impact, and how did you get along with the people in South America?
We got along fine with them.
Everybody was impressed with the air power.
This was a forerunner of the air power of the United States.
And we were at Old Kirtland, we later were at Ed Sack, and you know, calling it to the world.
We were decorated by the President of Brazil.
I was introduced to the diplomatic world for the first time.
A young second lieutenant, old Charlie Bond, who came from nothing.
Here I am in the capital of Rio de Janeiro, being honored by the President, and living on Copacabana Beach.
Wow.
Gee, eating it up, and given a medal.
A blue medal over there, just for participating in that flight.
And there's no doubt then that I knew that bombers were here to stay, transport aircraft, long-range aviation.
I knew it was here to stay.
But I still had love for fighters, and I still wanted to get in the 8th Pursuit Group right up the hangar line from us.
Were there any problems whatsoever with the South Americans?
I'm glad you asked that question.
We've always had problems with South America.
Well, ever since Teddy Roosevelt, we've had problems with South America.
And the tension sometimes between America and the South American countries runs high.
And I was wondering if there were, during New Deal and during the good neighbor policy of Roosevelt, he was trying to improve those relations.
And was there tension?
And this is one of the reasons we were making these flights.
Right, yeah.
Matter of fact, it was called a goodwill flight.
Mm-hmm.
And if you remember, after that, there were two or three of them made.
And in fact, before that, there was one or two made.
I was right in the middle of it.
But that's one of the longest ones, and the most general one.
As a matter of fact, it went all over South America.
But I distinctly remember, and this is something I learned, I remember definitely the German influence in Brazil.
Even in those days, 1939, was that right?
November 1939.
See, it was just before World War II.
No, the war had just started.
Yeah.
Right.
Right.
But we weren't in it.
No.
The United States wasn't in it.
No.
But you could see the German training, the influence.
I saw actual pictures of Hitler.
Really?
On walls of some of the buildings in Rio de Janeiro.
Knowing now what I didn't know then, the effective military assistance group, you know, where you provide military aid, support.
It was dominant, dominant, particularly in Brazil.
Germans were ready to take over Brazil.
And if you remember, when we did get into war, there was quite some naval activity up and down the Brazilian and Argentine.
As a matter of fact, quite a naval battle right in the Argentine area.
Looking back now, I could see it then developing.
And we'll get to this later on, but subsequently on the way to China, the Flying Tigers in 1941, I saw the Japanese and the Dutch effects in the Indies.
Surabaya Java gun emplacements, a new war was coming.
I want to stick right here on this very interesting topic of the Germans there.
You thought that the Germans were ready to take over in Brazil?
Looking back now, I can see that they were moving in as countries do today.
A perfect example is the way Russia has moved into Angola.
Oh, Afghanistan, it's obvious.
But the way they moved into Angola, the way they moved into Ethiopia, the way they moved into a lot of areas.
The current experience in Central America through Cuba.
Exactly.
Exactly.
Now how, back in 1939, was your mission to try to combat this German influence?
I'm sure that at the higher levels,
Just like we're doing today amongst nations.
Were you briefed before you went down there by State Department officials or anybody?
Yes.
As a matter of fact, a State Department official went with us in the form of General Matthew Ridgeway.
Oh.
He went with you?
Oh, yes.
Oh, yeah.
I bet.
And he was to advise the commander, General Andrews at that time.
That's not his name.
I'll think of it.
He's a Brigadier General in charge of what they call the General Headquarters of the Army Air Corps in Langley Field.
The name will come back to me in the transcript.
I'll get this.
You bet we were briefed.
What did they tell you?
Briefed on the conduct.
Briefed on, as a matter of fact, we were briefed.
I remember specifically.
What did they say?
What did the State Department officials tell you?
Well, the State Department official was really advising the commander.

He didn't make a talk to the crewman, but down a chain of command, we'd be told through our pilot of our crew, well, now look, we're going to this shindig tonight, and just be on your own, keep your mouth shut, observe, and then we'll talk about it later on.
In Brazil,
I think the real ultimate purpose of our trip was to try to impress the Brazilian government on the military capability.
In other words, four engine bombers of the United States military, at that time Army
Don't get locked in too much with the Germans.
Here we have foreign military airplanes that are flying over your country from the United States right now.
Show of force, looking back now, show of force is what we were doing.
You follow me on show of force?
Sure.
Military, I'm sure you do.
Well, that's what we were doing.
Did it work?
It was too late.
Too late.
See, this was November 39.
Sure.
Were the South Americans friendly toward you?
Yes.
As a matter of fact, you could see, looking back now, in South Park, Brazil, I remember part of the Brazilian Air Force.
As a matter of fact, I have a picture of that gentleman someplace in my album.
A very impressive, strictly oppression-type officer.
He was commander in the...
southern area of Brazil, the Air Force, and definitely oriented to the Germans.
As a matter of fact, I remember references to pictures of Hitler in this, I think it was in the embassy, not the American embassy, but some public building where we were having this, you know, he was
We were the one crew they gave a big shindig for.
And looking back now, there's no doubt that group, the Brazilian airmen, they were oriented to Germany, no doubt.
See, some of their aircraft, their equipment was German.
Yeah, sure.
I don't even, I can't remember.
Frankly, I don't even know if we had, I'm sure we had a semblance of a foreign military
policy, but there's no doubt that at that time, you know, Roosevelt was trying to make it stronger.
Sure.
Somewhat the way Reagan's trying to do today.
Sure.
What about the rest of the countries?
I mean, how'd you get along with the people in those countries?
Well, of course, we flew from Panama to Lima, Peru.
In Panama, I don't recall really we'd grown an American air base there.
I hardly even recall any Arabian children from Panamanian.
But in Lima, Peru, definitely very cordial and that along fine.
The German influence wasn't on the West Coast yet.
But then when he crossed over into Asuncion, Paraguay,
poverty-ridden country that was, I think, frankly, the only reason we stopped there is there was a logical place for refueling over the Andes, how to burn up fuel and all.
And we were treated great.
But in Rio, we were really wined and dined for the present on down.
As a matter of fact,
We took the president on my airplane in a formation flight over the bay of Rio de Janeiro.
The president of Brazil was on our airplane.
Where did he sit, up in a cockpit?
He sat up in a cockpit.
I got out of the co-pilot's cockpit, and he sat in my seat.
I think it was impressive to him.
As a matter of fact, I know it was, but it was too late.
It's like some time today, we're too late.
No, Ridgway.
I never did really understand his, he was a general, Brigadier General Ridgway, I know that.
I think what he was, was sort of head of the military intelligence.
He was an Army general, not an Army Air Corps general.
Terrific guy, by the way.
And by the way, he's not the Ridgway that was in Korea, I don't think he is.
No, the one that was certainly in the Philippines.
That's not the same one.
This man had to have connections with the intelligence agency.
This is Matthew Ridgeway, though.
No.
No.
Oh, that's what you said before.
Did I say Matthew Ridgeway?
Mm-hmm.
I'd have to.
Well, it's not the same Ridgeway.
Oh, OK. Maybe I said Matthew because of the name.
But it's not the same Ridgeway as the one in the Philippines or the great chief of staff.
Yeah.
You know, wait, I'm going to have to check that later on.
This could have been the same one.
Sure.
I'm going to have to check that.
I think it was.
I said Matthew, didn't I?
Yeah.
Well, it must be.
I'm not sure that's who it was, but I'll have to check this on you.
fine on the transcript.
What kind of man was he?
You could never figure out what his job was.
But he was definitely in the intelligence area.
I am sure that man then was collecting information on the Germans.
I'm sure he was.
Did he ever discuss any of this with you?
No, not with the second lieutenant.
But even then, I knew in my lowly possession of a crew member and a brand new second lieutenant in the Air Force that
This man had a definite mission, and he was always with the Brigadier General commanding the whole flight.
He was always right up to his side.
What kind of man was he?
He was an impressive person, very diplomatic, strictly the diplomat type, not the military type.
very gregarious, likable.
As an Army general, I don't know how competent he was.
He was just on our flight as a passenger.
But he was easy to communicate with.
Oh, yes.
As a matter of fact, he was a perfect diplomat.
I'm sure he was the diplomat for the flight.
And he carried his own briefcase and papers.
Now, tell me, after you returned, then what did you do with the bomber group?

Well, after we returned, it was then, you know, see, this was in November 39, and we're approaching the year of 1940, and, you know, we're already, Europeans were already locked in combat, and there was a strange war over there at that time.
Then, we began to see it, so we began to expand the Air Force.
The second bomb group was
split up and formed the Cadres for two groups.
The newest one being established at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Florida, and so happened the one I was reassigned to.
I wanted to go with General LeMay, at that time Lieutenant LeMay, in another outfit that was going to spin off called an observation squadron, which
that was later to be the so-called reconnaissance arm of the United States.
And Colonel May went off in that area.
You were asked to be with him?
No.
I was assigned at how, I don't know, but I was assigned to the 43rd Bomb Squadron.
It was going to be at Tampa Air Force Base.
And then we began to arrange for that trip.
I was selected to, because of my
infantry experience being in the 15th Field Artillery when I tried to get to West Point Prep Security to lead the motor convoy for the second bomb group.
Well, actually the bomb group was going to be organized down at Tampa.
So I led a group of vehicles about
get to fly the airplane down there.
And we actually went into a place called a groove field while MacDill was being completed.
I'm sure you've heard of MacDill Air Force.
I landed the first airplane on that runway at MacDill Air Force before it was completed.
Sort of illegally, but I did it.
And then of course we began to train there.
How large was the groove?
The aircraft, by the way, were split up, and we had three B-17s and about five or six B-18s, and an A-17, and then a trainer airplane, PT-13.
Just the makings of it.
Sure.
Just woefully unequipped.
Yeah.
And how many men?
How many what?
How many men?
Oh, gee, I don't remember how many men.
I'd say we had about, in my squadron, we must have had...
six or eight crews for bombing air, for a bomber.
Strictly a cadre, you know, storming around.
And we had to bring the new pilots in from a flying school and build it up.
So you were building, yeah.
Yeah, building.
And lo and behold, right in the middle of that come, this is around
of 1941 we had to get aircraft to the British RAF, and the only way to do it was to have Americans ferry them.
I was a two and four engine qualified pilot, so I was picked to be part of the hurry-up organized United States Army Air Corps ferrying command.
I was sent out to Burbank, California.

out in Lockheed Hudson Bomber building by Lockheed to supply those horrible things, clear up to Montreal where the RAF would pick them up and fly them over to England and that's the bombers they had for the early part of the war against Hitler.
And what kind of bombers were we giving them?
Lockheed Hudson Bombers.
Those old Lockheed Hudson Bombers that couldn't carry more than two, three, five hundred pounds.
And actually didn't even have a bombing system in them.
But it was helped.
at least we'd get an airplane with the idea of eventually getting equipment.
Sure.
Now, as far as the British were concerned, did you have an opportunity to meet any of the British representatives?
At that time, no.
As a matter of fact, we'd fly the airplane up to Montreal, get out of the airplane, take our parachute,
commercial airliner and fly all the way back to Long Beach, California, then start the whole thing over again.
Now when you flew, the bombers up there, how often did you have to stop?

We'd fly from, I'd take off from Long Beach, my first stop would be Henson Air Force Base in Dallas, Texas, because that's where I lived, because I also lived with my current wife at that time, Daytoner.
And they wouldn't mind if you went sort of an indirect route?
Well, no, yeah.
That was one of the direct routes.
As a matter of fact, they picked it for us.
It was the most direct route, you know, refueling and all.
And also, weather dictated sometimes.
We had two or three routes.
And because of my bombing experience, when they formed these crews out there, I was one of the lead crews.
And we were restricted to visual flights only.
We couldn't fly on instruments.
See, a lot of them were brand new pilots, comparatively speaking.
Sure.
So you were a veteran.
At that time, there were about 2,500 officers in the entire Army Air Corps.
About 2,500 officers.
By that time, I was first lieutenant, by the way.
So you were the pilot of the plane, and I was the co-pilot.
Yeah, I was the pilot.
Then we'd fly from there up to From Texas up to
You'd fly first to Texas and then from Texas.
Then to usually, for some reason or another, we'd always go to Fort Wayne, Indiana.
And then from there, we'd go to Montreal.
You had to make about two stops between Los Angeles and Montreal because of the range of the airplane.
And we'd just go back and forth.
And how long would it take you to fly between Montreal and California?
Normally, I'd stay overnight at Dallas.
And quite often we'd make the next flight in one day.
I mean two days, make the whole flight in two days.
Sometimes I'd have an engine problem or one of the guys, and we'd fly three or four airplanes together in sort of a loose formation.
And maybe some problem would cause us to wait over, you know, or maybe weather or something.
And I've had, well, sometimes it'd take maybe three or four days to make that trip.
That started, I believe, that started around February or March, I believe.
Or April, somewhere in there, spring.

And then it was while I was a member of that, and doing that work, that one of my ex-buddies, my roommate at MacDill Air Force Base, Gibble Griller, called me on the telephone to tell me about Skip Adair recruiting guys for the
American Volunteer Group in China.
And then this opened up the story, of course, of the Flying Tigers.
Now, why was I interested in this?
That's the question.
I still wanted to get in fighters.
And here I was ferrying American aircraft, doing my part to get them to England, who was fighting in the war.
I knew we were going to get in war.
I was convinced.
And third, I wanted a regular commission.
I was a career officer by then.
I'd been a reserve officer all along.
I had never had college at all.
I wanted to be a regular officer.
I was committed.
I didn't want to be an aeronautical engineer.
I wanted to be a pilot in the United States Army.
I wanted to be a pilot in the Air Force.
And you could get a regular commission by volunteering for the Flying Tigers?
Well, I figured that we were going to get in the war.
There was only about 2,500, incidentally, go back a minute.
I did take an examination one time at Langley Field between when I first reported there in February of 39 up until early part of 41 when we went down to Tampa.
I took an examination of, it was by some senator's name, Morrison Rowdy, or I can't remember the name, but it's,
You could take examinations and get a regular commission that way.
They'd select very few.
A Brownell Act, I think they called it, B-R-O-W-N-E-L, I think that's the way it's called.
But I didn't have college.
Sure.
And they were held against me.
So I knew I had to have college some way, but this comes up later on.
I knew if we got in war, and I knew that if I had combat experience, I knew in China,
I knew we'd be clashing with the Japanese.
The Japanese were already fighting the Chinese.
And I knew, as a matter of fact, we were in on all practical purposes going to be the Chinese airport.
So I knew I'd have combat experience.
And I'd signed a one-year contract of Flying Tigers, AVG.
Then I'd come back home, and here we are getting ready, well, tracking in the war by then, and expanding, obviously.
Then certainly they'd give me a regular commission.
I just knew it.
I hadn't made it.
So that was one of the reasons that you wanted to get an applying doctor.
There were three reasons.
Three reasons.
I wanted to get fighters.
I wanted to get a regular commission.
And I wanted to make some money to put my mother and father in a home that was paid for.
And tell me about the money.
How'd they pay you?
I'd get $500 for every aircraft I shot down.
And that was the main thing that attracted me.
I figured I'd get in combat, and I'd shoot Japanese down.
Plus, in fact, I got $600 a month as a wingman, and all my expenses paid, and so forth and so on.
And who paid for your expenses?
Who gave you the money?
This came out of Lend-Lease money, really.
The Chinese government paid, but it was originally given by Americans.
It was Americans.
But when you got a check, did it say the Republic of China on it?
When you got a check, it was, the check was made out, how was it?
What was that corporation?
Air America?
CAMCO.
CAMCO.
Central Aircraft Manufacturing Company.
CIA, if you will.
Or, we'll forget that remark.
But Lend-Lease.
Oh, we all know that.
Well, sure.
Lend-Lease, OK. Lend-Lease, really.
At least money.
But see, here I'm getting into dickerings between foreign countries again.
China didn't have an air force.
Chennault was over there.
He'd been away since about 1937.
And this is a story you should hear.
How did the Flying Tigers ever get started, ABG?
I'm sure you've heard of Sun, S-W-N-G, a very influential Chinese man.
and needing help with fighting the Japanese.
Through his State Department offices, he gave an interview to the JISMO with Chenault.
Chenault was over there with the Generalissimo.
They'd been trying to set up a train to train a polyglot bunch of, even some Russians.
And it was some sort of an air force for the Chinese, and no more than three or four months it tracked up all the aircraft, and it was just no good.
And Chenault got the idea of recruiting some top-notch American pilots and aircrew, and sold Soong on it.
Soong got the ear of President Roosevelt.

And in a 30-minute dissertation to the President of the United States, Soong, just a second, honey, and you can't find this in writing anyplace, Chenault talked President Roosevelt into letting him Soong or Chenault?
No.
Soong and Chenault.
Oh, they were both in Washington, D.C. Oh, yes.
And a madam.
And a madam.
Yeah.
Generalist of Moshe and Kashek's wife.
Yeah.
The biggest beggar in the world.
Yeah.
But very influential.
Those three, in 1937.
Is there a 37 or 38?
No, wait a minute.
This could have been around 1940, that late.
Maybe early 1941.
I have a document someplace.
At any rate, in 30 minutes, the President told Chenault, yes, I'll
give authorized to own channels and then you can start tomorrow.

But you will be permitted to recruit any pilot and any air maintenance man that you want to recruit from the United States Army Air Corps or the United States Navy or the United States Marine Corps that will volunteer to go with you.
You've got an open ticket to go.
And he began to recruit.
How about private?
Oh yeah, if he wanted to.
But he wanted military training.
Sure he did.
To my knowledge, there was not one single civilian commercial type pilot in our group.
It was 48, I'd say 47% Air Force, maybe 2% Marine, and 51% Navy.
There were a hundred pilots.

He was going to recruit a hundred pilots and he was going to get a hundred P-40s that were sitting in crates in Buffalo at the Curtis Wright outfit that were turned down by the British for the North African campaign.
Why were they turned down?
Already obsolete.
They never coped with the Major Schmidt and Falkirk aircraft.
This was like a Hurricane Hunter type aircraft.
And at that time, see, we didn't know much about Negro.
Right.
OK, let's go.
OK, we want to find out about how you left the service, got in the flying tires, and how that worked.
I mean, legally, how did that work?
Well, see, we had a land lease arrangement that was set up.
I guess originally for the European area, but extended it worldwide.
This is when the Chinese jumped aboard, and then it was coincidental that they had Chennault over there trying to develop them an air force to fight Japan.
They'd been fighting Japan for several years.
Yeah, since 37.
Sure.
And Chennault had just practically given up with any of the efforts.
the ways that the Chinese were trying to do it.
So then they got this idea with the backing and .
And soon, and of course Roosevelt, and then we were practically in war anyhow.
And whether it was legal or not, that's the reason I say I have never seen anything in writing on this.
And I'm told, much personally, that there's nothing written any place.
Just when all gave, I mean, the president of Roanoke gave instructions over the telephone.
And next thing I know, I got this call one night out at Long Beach from Gibbo Grover, one of my roommates that I lived with and flew together at the 43rd bomb group there in McDale.
And he said, you always want to get in fighters.
You've got a chance.
you ever hear of General Chennault?
And I said, well, yeah, I've heard of him.
Make a long story short, well, Gip Adair had been this guy that was going, he was an ex-retired Air Force guy, and he happened to be a friend of Gibbo Broder's.
When he told Gibbo that at McDill, he was authorized to go on the base and recruit pilots.
So Gibbo comes, I know a man that'd be dying to get in your outfit, so who is it?
Charlie Bond, well.
Kibo called me and gave me the phone number, and I called Kip Adair, and he explained generally what he was on to.
One-year contract paid by the Chinese, which was out of Lend-Lease money.
And that's the way the whole thing was financed.
And when we get in combat, if you get in combat with Japanese, you get $500 in cash for every airplane you shoot down, deposited to a bank of your choice in the United States.
All your transportation expenses will be paid.
Your living expenses in China will be paid.
